Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: PDE Techniques for Battery Management Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

The project will develop state estimators, parameter estimators, and controllers for Lithium-ion batteries. Both the electrochemical dynamics in individual battery cells (the distribution of currents, potentials, and concentrations of lithium in electrolyte and in the solid particles in the electrodes) and thermal dynamics in battery packs (the excursions of temperature caused by the electric processes in cells and leading to the potentially fatal ?thermal runaway?) will be tacked. Each of the two systems is modeled by coupled systems of nonlinear PDEs. Estimation and control designs that will be developed for these mathematically complex systems will be the main intellectual outcome of the project. As the industrial partner in this GOALI program, Bosch will contribute its vast expertise in battery physics, modeling, and in the state-of-the-art in battery management systems. Bosch will also provide its experimental facilities for the testing of results.

Broader Impact

The broader impacts will include the PI?s continued effort in mentoring underrepresented students, including women, Hispanics, and African-Americans, and an outreach to UCSD?s Preuss School, one of the nation's top ten high schools, which enrolls mostly inner-city kids of Hispanic background. The high-school students will be introduced by the PI and by the Co-PI from Bosch to the basics of energy storage and automotive control technologies. The PI will work on organizing a workshop on control of energy storage systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Technologies for storage of electric energy are central to a range of applications, from transportation systems, including electric and hybrid vehicles, to portable electronics. Lithium-ion batteries have emerged as the most promising technology for such applications, thanks to their high energy density, lack of hysteresis, and low self-discharge currents. One of the most important problems in battery technology is achieving safe and reliable operation at low cost.

 

Large packs of batteries, required in high-power applications such as submarines, satellites, and electric automobiles, are prone to thermal runaways, which can result in damage on a large scale. Safety is typically ensured by over-design, which amounts to packaging and passive cooling techniques designed for worst- case scenarios. Both the weight and the cost of the batteries can be considerably lowered by developing models of thermal dynamics in battery packs and model-based estimators and control laws. Detailed numerically-oriented models (often referred to as CFD or FEM models), which are used for computationally intensive off-line tests of operating scenarios, are unsuitable for real-time implementation.

 

We have developed models of thermal dynamics in large battery packs in the form of two-dimensional partial differential equations (2D PDEs). The models are considerable simplifications of the full CFD/FEM model and therefore offer the advantage of being tractable for model-based state estimation, parameter estimation, and‚îêcontrol design. Our models emphasize the inhomogeneity of the battery pack medium, where, the cells and the materials they are enclosed in have very different thermal conductivity properties, where the thermal dynamics are coupled with the electrical dynamics which act as heat sources, and where cooling systems, passive or controlled, may be introduced to manage the temperature distribution in a battery pack. With extensive numerical tests and parametric studies we have shown that our models match the detailed CFD models well, while taking much less time to compute.

 

We have also generated major results for estimating the state of charge (SOC) and state of health (SOH) of PDE models of Lithium-ion batteries. These estimators perform simultaneous estimation of the unmeasured concentration distribution in the battery cells and of the unknown parameters of the battery cell. The estimator is synthesized from the so-called single particle model (SPM). This estimator employs only the measurement of the terminal voltage and battery current, while estimating the spatially distributed concentration of Lithium ions within the battery. In addition, we designed state-of-health (SOH) estimators, framed as parameter identifiers for the parabolic PDEs models of the battery electrochemistry. One of the main challenges we overcame is the nonlinear dependence of the battery voltage on the concentration and current, as well as the nonlinear parameterization of the battery voltage in terms of its physical parameters. We employed the swapping identification method for unknown parameters in the diffusion partial differential equation (PDE). A nonlinear least squares method is applied to the output function to identify its unknown parameters. These identification algorithms are synthesized from the single particle model (SPM).

 

We have then employed the adaptive state esimators for SOC and SOH in the development of a battery management system that maintains the battery's internal (unmeasurable) states within prespecified constraint using the reference governor approach, while charging the battery as fast as possible. We have demonstrated, in numerical simulations on a high-fidelity model, an increase in the battery's energy capacity of 4% and an increase of power capacity of 37%.
